thread.title: As American Athletic Conference gains prestige, so do Temple Owls
thread.title_full: As American Athletic Conference gains prestige, so do Temple Owls

author: John Smallwood,
title: As American Athletic Conference gains prestige, so do Temple Owls
text:
AS A PASSENGER on the Temple Bandwagon, I must remind you it is not yet the time to be concerned with the minutiae of week-by-week considerations.
The first ranking from the College Football Selection Committee is not scheduled to be released until Nov. 3, so things can change before then.
Still, it is never too early to draw attention, and there is no question that the Owls, undefeated going into Saturday's Homecoming game against Tulane at Lincoln Financial Field, have put themselves on the national radar.
In ESPN.com's latest power rankings, Temple (4-0) is tied at No. 25 with fellow American Athletic Conference member Houston (which was 4-0 entering last night's game against SMU).
More coverage Latest college sports videos SHOP: Collegiate Sportswear & Merchandise In the Associated Press poll, Temple is technically, 29th, having received 23 votes, while Houston is 28th, with 31 votes.
In the coaches' poll, Temple is 31st, with 16 votes, while Houston is 35th, with 11 votes. Right now, the coaches like AAC member Memphis (5-0), which is ranked 25th.
What provides some extra boost to the Bandwagon as it chugs along to its final destination, - either the Peach Bowl in Atlanta or the Fiesta Bowl in Glendale, Ariz. - is the number of AAC schools recognized.
With teams having played four or five games, the American has established itself as the best among the "Group of Five" conferences, the tier just below the Power Five in college football.
The highest ranked champion from one of those conferences - which includes the Mid-American, Conference USA, Mountain West and Sun Belt - is guaranteed an at-large bid into a College Football Playoffs New Year's Six bowl game, either the Peach or Fiesta this season.
The AAC's status will be big going into Selection Sunday on Dec. 6, when the College Football Playoff semifinals and other NY6 bowl bids are announced.
Realistically, if Temple runs the table in its conference schedule and wins the AAC Championship Game on Dec. 5, the Owls must be champions to be considered for the automatic bid.
A loss on Halloween at Lincoln Financial Field to non-conference foe Notre Dame is the only one they could suffer that would not eliminate them from consideration over Boise State, which now has an established reputation.
The overall strength of the AAC, however, is a NY6 lifeline for Temple, as long as it handles its business.
Boise State (4-1), of the Mountain West, is the highest-ranked team from the Group of Five. With wins over Pac-12 Washington, and at ACC Virginia, the Broncos are 24th in the coaches poll and 25th in the AP poll.
Boise has only Mountain West opponents left on its schedule, so it is unlikely to lose again.
Still the Mountain West lacks overall quality, so, while Boise, which lost to Brigham Young, will likely hold its Top 25 ranking, the opportunity to rise significantly will not be there.
That does not apply to the AAC's best teams: Temple, Houston, Memphis and Navy, all of which entered Week 6 undefeated. The AAC already has wins over Louisville, Kansas, Miami, Penn State and Virginia Tech, which is, among the Group of Five, the most wins over Power 5 schools.
Those Power 5 schools will win games during conference play, thus enhancing the profiles of the AAC schools that beat them.
For Temple, that opening win over Penn State still has more to give.
It is not a stretch to think that if any of the undefeated AAC schools runs the table, it will likely become that highest ranked champion from the Group of Five.
The CFP Selection Committee has said strength of schedule plays a large role in its rankings for the semifinals and the other NY6 bowls.
The best way in for a Group of Five team is to play in the strongest conference and beat Power 5 opponents.
Now let us wrap this back to why things look good for Temple. The Owls won at AAC preseason favorite Cincinnati, which has not lived up to hype, but did just handily beat Miami, of the ACC.
Temple plays in the AAC East. Houston, Memphis and Navy play in the West, meaning only one even has a possibility of finishing the regular season undefeated.
Temple does not have Houston or Navy in the regular season. The Owls play Memphis at home on Nov. 21, a week after the Tigers play at Houston and two weeks after they host Navy.
All things are in line for Temple to host the inaugural AAC Championship Game.
If the Owls are undefeated, including wins over Penn State and Notre Dame, an undefeated Toledo, not Boise State, would be the only Group of Five team that could be considered along with the Owls.
The Rockets (4-0) are 24th in the AP poll and have Power 5 wins at Arkansas and over Iowa State. Those wins would not equal Temple beating Penn State and Notre Dame - plus the AAC is 3-0 against the Mid-American Conference.
It is a 784 miles from Philadelphia to Atlanta, a sprint, compared with the 2,386-mile marathon to Glendale. The Temple Bandwagon is up for either.
